title: 820-2915 chime no video
message: Did you checked the VIN-Pin 6 or the resistor R9500?

title: 820-2915 chime no video
message: Have you tried giving heat to GPU????

title: 820-2915 chime no video
message:
[QUOTE="Crizz, post: 2850"]Did you checked the VIN-Pin 6 or the resistor R9500?[/QUOTE]
R9500 is OK, VIN is-Pin6 is 12.25V

There is no point heating the GPU if it's not getting 1.5V

title: 820-2915 chime no video
message:
actually aprendiz was asking if you tried to give your GPU a little bit of heat :D
apr. ~150-160C
If the machine will work after that you know your GPU is dead

title: 820-2915 chime no video
message:

message: Did you check for a short on both busses? Pin 3 and 5 get voltage?

title: 820-2915 chime no video
message:
best solution for chime no video
0.check if external monitior works
1.use known good screen with ldvd cable
2.change lvds connector in board in precise/ precision way....
3. then you start checking pin 2,3,4 on lvds connector

title: 820-2915 chime no video
message: I am not sure if the board would power up those rails without the presence of a GPU chip (need expert input here) but these motherboards do have a history of GPU failures and if I had to consider which connection points fail the most are those which convey current.

message: I just took L9510 off, U9500 was giving that 1V so there is a short to ground on the other side, right. So the GPU is fucked up, like all boards.

title: 820-2915 chime no video
message: You cannot take L9510 off and expect the regulator to still work! Is there a short to GND?

title: 820-2915 chime no video
message: Remove C9560 (tantalum cap) and check if short is gone, if does not, apply 0.5V with power supply on that rail and see what is getting hot (do not limit current), if you do not find anything hot go a bit high on voltage until something gets hot, of course do not pass over from 1V........

title: 820-2915 chime no video
message:

Already done that, can't see nothing getting hot. Oh god... short still there

title: 820-2915 chime no video

title: 820-2915 chime no video
message: The AMD is a 216-0810084 1GB, I have a board with a 216-809000 512GB, is it compatible?

title: 820-2915 chime no video
message: If anyone is wondering, it should be compatible, only check page 77 of the schematic, it depends on what memory brand (Samsung/Hinnyx) and how much VRAM you have (512MB/1GB) to solder or not any other resistors (R8611/R8612/R8613). 216-0810084 is compatible with 216-0810005 aswell.

title: 820-2915 chime no video
message:
[QUOTE="Vinny, post: 2926"]If anyone is wondering, it should be compatible, only check page 77 of the schematic, it depends on what memory brand (Samsung/Hinnyx) and how much VRAM you have (512MB/1GB) to solder or not any other resistors (R8611/R8612/R8613). 216-0810084 is compatible with 216-0810005 aswell.[/QUOTE]


216-0810084 is directly compatible with 216-0810005? No modifications necessary?

also could you please make a truth table about compatibility between 216-0810084 and 216-809000 including combinations of Vram and required resistors?

title: 820-2915 chime no video
message:
You can replace 216-0810084 with 216-0810005 but it requires soldering in a resistor that I have to look up since I have not done this in over a year. Either way all of those GPUs you will find are either someone else's shit stock, fake, or reballed.

The 216-809000 used to be available with a lesser fake/bs/reballed crap rate. I actually have a spool here I will never use. Send me your address and I'll send you a few for free.

message:

title: 820-2915 chime no video
message:
SOLVED!!!

2 resistors missing around GPU, and soldered the resistor needed to detect 1GB Samsung VRAM

This is my succesfull board repair anthem, and I dance to it:

[url]https://youtu.be/qNMzIRnXziw?t=66[/url]
